Then when updating your PR branch use \"-f\" to force the update to your personal repo (never use \"-f\" or \"rebase\" when interacting with the Apache repo). Rebase makes for clean updates to PRs.\n\nYou can visually see the difference using this site: https://onlywei.github.io/explain-git-with-d3/#rebase\n",

    "created_at": "2016-09-20T14:03:03Z",
    "updated_at": "2016-09-20T14:03:23Z",
    "author_association": "CONTRIBUTOR",
    "body": "@ToivoAdams yup, it's complaining because when you \"rebase\" you are re-writing history. When you try to push it's out of sync with the branch you're pushing to and it tells you to \"pull\" in order to be coordinated. By doing a \"force push\", you're saying \"forget whatever the current state of the branch is, what I'm pushing is correct\".\n\nThis is very nice when you're doing it to your own branch/PR but it's pretty self-explanatory how bad it could be doing to the Apache repo.\n\nI'm gonna take a look at the new PR now. Feel free to close this one whenever you're able.\n",
    "performed_via_github_app": null
  }
]

      "repos_url": "https://api.github.com/users/JPercivall/repos",
      "events_url": "https://api.github.com/users/JPercivall/events{/privacy}",
      "received_events_url": "https://api.github.com/users/JPercivall/received_events",
      "type": "User",
      "site_admin": false
    },
    "created_at": "2016-09-20T14:03:03Z",
    "updated_at": "2016-09-20T14:03:23Z",
    "author_association": "CONTRIBUTOR",
    "body": "@ToivoAdams yup, it's complaining because when you \"rebase\" you are re-writing history. When you try to push it's out of sync with the branch you're pushing to and it tells you to \"pull\" in order to be coordinated. By doing a \"force push\", you're saying \"forget whatever the current state of the branch is, what I'm pushing is correct\".\n\nThis is very nice when you're doing it to your own branch/PR but it's pretty self-explanatory how bad it could be doing to the Apache repo.\n\nI'm gonna take a look at the new PR now. Feel free to close this one whenever you're able.\n",
    "performed_via_github_app": null
  }
]

It seemed easy enough, but the validation issues probably out weigh the value.\n\nPostponing until [NIFI-813|https://issues.apache.org/jira/browse/NIFI-813] provides a means to handle potential errors, but if mixing Regex and Expression Language can only be handled with a Failure relationships, maybe it's better to not mix the them and allow separate properties so the Regex can be validated and the EL expression can produce a list of attributes that can be ignored if they don't exist.   Thoughts?\n",

    "updated_at": "2015-11-17T17:48:37Z",
    "author_association": "CONTRIBUTOR",
    "body": "Was combing through the actual PR.  Not sure I am onboard with the additional property and misunderstood what the intent was.  There was a similar effort with the Character Set Validator where we validated that the specified charset was valid if specified, otherwise just that a string was returned via EL should it be an expression.\n\nRegex Validator, by default evaluates the EL and then applies validation to the resulting \"regex\".  Would it be reasonable to have a separate validator that matches the semantics of what you are looking for (akin to that of how ConvertCharacterSet functions)?  Should be okay from the standpoint of compatibility and non-breaking changes.\n\nAdditionally, playing with this a bit, I did a blanket delete (.*) which leads to some bad effects in terms of the framework as the UUID is removed and puts us in a bad state.\n",

    "updated_at": "2015-11-17T20:21:57Z",
    "author_association": "CONTRIBUTOR",
    "body": "@jskora Sorry, I think a few of the different contexts from messages between you, @trkurc and I made communication a bit jumbled.\n\nTo that end, I am onboard with regex, but personally, would not want a second field to the same focus.  The issue that is present is more of an issue with the underlying framework and its handling with EL.  What I was suggesting with the regex validator is applying the validation to an entered string, but bypassing validation for where these values are specified on a per FlowFile basis via EL.  What is missing is not so much the granularity as it is the ability to route failures which is currently nonexistent and was some of what @trkurc was asking about what the appropriate tradeoffs/concessions are given the current state of the framework.  To this idea, I am more for keeping consistent with how we are now and letting this get addressed with the needed framework adjustments as we move forward.\n\nTo your question regarding deletion, that is certainly not on you or any extension developer.  As highlighted by NIFI-1181/1182, these values are safeguarded but your processor exposed the bug of where it was not safeguarded in this context.\n",

    "created_at": "2015-02-18T04:30:51Z",
    "updated_at": "2015-02-18T04:30:51Z",
    "author_association": "CONTRIBUTOR",
    "body": "Review Findings:\n- Adjusted the LICENSE/NOTICE information for Standard Nar, NiFi source root, and NiFi assembly.\n- Can we cache the compiled JsonPaths [they are threadsafe, etc..]?\n  - If so whenever onPropertyModified is triggers we know to invalidate the cache.  Can let it get refreshed during the next onTrigger.\n- EvaluateJsonPath: Instead of pulling some set batch size use the @SupportsBatching annotation and the framework can take care of this for you and will do so in a manner that favors user defined tolerances for latency vs throughput.  In addition this removes the need for the for loop, the flowfileloop goto, etc..  But it does make the previous suggestion more important (caching compiled JsonPaths)\n- Another contributor has provided an auto-documentation mechanism.  Not sure of its status for being pulled in just yet though. In the mean time please consider adding documentation pages in src/main/resources/docs....\n- EvaluateJsonPath: Line 207.  Is exception handling the only possible option for handling/detecting this?  Exceptions create a shocking amount of stress on GC and overall JVM performance at rate.  Having exception handling be key to the flow control will greatly limit the applicability of this processor for truly high volume processing.  If there is no alternative it is probably worth documenting this fact as a caveat for users to know in the docs for the processor.  If you'd like to see just how horrible exceptions are for throughput of the JVM do a simple test of Integer.parseInt to parse a String (when some of the inputs could be non-Integers) vs a regex to test first if it appears to be an Int then using Integer.parseInt.\n- EvaluateJsonPath: Consider telling the provenance event reporter if you modified the content of the flow file and providing some details about the change.\n- SplitJson: Exception based handling again to be avoided if possible.\n- Both Processors: It appears to be that the library will load the full input stream in memory then return results, splits, etc..  If so that provides important information about its applicability on large JSON documents.  If so please document this concern with the processor so users can consider this and its impact to the heap/memory space.\n- SplitJson: Consider telling the provenance event reporter that the splits are forks from the original.\n\nSummary: Really good stuff here.  This will be a very helpful processor.  Please consider making the suggested modifications.  I will push to origin this new branch NIFI-360.  Please modify off that and we can work from that PR.  Thanks!\n",
    "performed_via_github_app": null

    "created_at": "2018-05-09T12:52:01Z",
    "updated_at": "2018-05-09T12:52:01Z",
    "author_association": "MEMBER",
    "body": "@sebastian-nagel one thing I noticed with OkHttp is that its [ConnectionPool](https://github.com/square/okhttp/blob/master/okhttp/src/main/java/okhttp3/ConnectionPool.java) (default maxIdle 5, with eviction after 5 mins)  struggles when used with many threads and different hostnames, which would typically be the case with Nutch (and StormCrawler). I have seen an average of 1.5s and up to 6s contention on the ConnectionPool, my guess is that [the cleanup method](https://github.com/square/okhttp/blob/master/okhttp/src/main/java/okhttp3/ConnectionPool.java#L199) and its synchronized block is the main culprit. It iterates on all the connections but removes only the one which has been idle for the longest.\r\n\r\nApart from that okHTTP is great: pretty robust and less arcane than Apache HTTPClient IMHO.\r\n",
    "performed_via_github_app": null

    "body": "All TODOs addressed in last commits. The unit tests for NUTCH-2549 are ported now. Some failed and are ignored for now. This seems acceptable because okhttp only supports HTTP/1.1 and HTTP/2 [but not HTTP/1.0](http://square.github.io/okhttp/3.x/okhttp/okhttp3/OkHttpClient.Builder.html#protocols-java.util.List-).\r\n- no HTTP status line (that conforms only to HTTP/0.9)\r\n- no multi-line headers (deprecated with HTTP/1.1])\r\n- also HTTP status line needs to be syntactically correct\r\n- ignoring errors reading non-200 payload: exception could eventually be caught\r\n```\r\n% grep -A1 -i testcase build/protocol-okhttp/test/TEST-org.apache.nutch.protocol.okhttp.TestBadServerResponses.txt\r\nTestcase: testBadHttpServer took 0.444 sec\r\nTestcase: testNoStatusLine took 0.083 sec\r\n        Caused an ERROR\r\n--\r\nTestcase: testOverlongHeader took 0.116 sec\r\nTestcase: testContentLengthNotANumber took 0.13 sec\r\nTestcase: testHeaderSpellChecking took 0.101 sec\r\nTestcase: testMultiLineHeader took 0.074 sec\r\n        FAILED\r\n--\r\nTestcase: testHeaderWithColon took 0.103 sec\r\n        Caused an ERROR\r\n--\r\nTestcase: testChunkedContent took 0.09 sec\r\nTestcase: testRequestNotStartingWithSlash took 0.077 sec\r\nTestcase: testIgnoreErrorInRedirectPayload took 0.073 sec\r\n        Caused an ERROR\r\n```",

    "updated_at": "2015-10-03T07:06:02Z",
    "author_association": "CONTRIBUTOR",
    "body": "I missed something before voting: seems like we should think about meaning of default values.\n\nIf user takes default configuration, tuples could be timed out on low throughput bolt because default will be changed to use batch but don't set tick tuple for flushing. \n(Please note that default value of flushIntervalSecs is 0)\n\nIt breaks backward compatibility, and since Storm should also consider low latency requirement, I think there's no reason to change to use batch by default.\n",

    "url": "https://api.github.com/repos/apache/storm/issues/comments/145211043",

    "author_association": "CONTRIBUTOR",
    "body": "This patch allows a worker to properly detect that the connection to a peer becomes unavailable -- for whatever reason (the remote worker is dead or restarting, there was a network glitch, etc). Also, any reconnection attempts are now async so that reconnecting will not block other activities of the worker (such as sending messages to other workers it is still connected to).\n\nSo to your question: this patch includes the case of the worker that remained alive trying to (re)connect to a dead peer.\n\nDoes that help?\n",

    "created_at": "2015-02-12T10:44:26Z",
    "updated_at": "2015-02-12T11:08:39Z",
    "author_association": "CONTRIBUTOR",
    "body": "Thanks for your feedback, Nathan.\n\nAs far as I understand this patch does not enable backpressure. But: because there is no backpressure (yet) that we can rely on, this patch will improve at least the situation during the startup phase of a topology to a) prevent that an unacked topo will lose messages during the startup, and b) we do not need to unnecessarily replay messages in case of acked topos during their startup.  This is achieved by checking that all worker connections are ready before the topology starts processing data.\n\nSo backpressure is still an open feature. Backpressure was IIRC mentioned in the initial PR because there was a deficiency (dating back to a ZMQ related TODO) that caused problems related to this PR/Storm tickets (329, 404, and one more).  However, this patch does make the best of the current situation even in the absence of backpressure.  But first and foremost this patch fixes a (critical) cascading failure that can bring Storm clusters to a halt.\n\nPlease correct me if I'm mistaken in my summary.\n",
    "performed_via_github_app": null
  },

    "created_at": "2015-02-12T20:37:55Z",
    "updated_at": "2015-02-12T20:37:55Z",
    "author_association": "CONTRIBUTOR",
    "body": "If you need at-least-once processing you must use an acking topology, which will allow Storm to replay lost messages.  If instead you go with an unacking topology (= no guaranteed message processing) then you may run into data loss.  There re pros and cons for each variant, and e.g. in our case we use both depending on the use case.\n\nAlso: The semantics described above have been in Storm right from the beginning.  None of these have been changed by this pull request.\n\n> On 12.02.2015, at 20:01, Daniel Schonfeld notifications@github.com wrote:\n> \n> Doesn't dropping the messages coming from a non ack/fail caring spout negate the 'at least once' attempt of storm? I mean doesn't that kinda force you to make all your spouts ack/fail aware where before you could have gotten away without it?\n> \n> In other words. There is a chance that if the worker that died is the one containing the spout and if the first bolt is located on another worker, that technically at-least once wasn't tried but rather fell to the floor right away.\n> \n> \n> Reply to this email directly or view it on GitHub.\n",
    "performed_via_github_app": null
  },

  {
    "url": "https://api.github.com/repos/apache/storm/issues/comments/74914806",
    "html_url": "https://github.com/apache/storm/pull/429#issuecomment-74914806",
    "issue_url": "https://api.github.com/repos/apache/storm/issues/429",
    "id": 74914806,
    "node_id": "MDEyOklzc3VlQ29tbWVudDc0OTE0ODA2",
    "user": {
      "login": "nathanmarz",
      "id": 131416,
      "node_id": "MDQ6VXNlcjEzMTQxNg==",
      "avatar_url": "https://avatars0.githubusercontent.com/u/131416?v=4",
      "gravatar_id": "",
      "url": "https://api.github.com/users/nathanmarz",
      "html_url": "https://github.com/nathanmarz",
      "followers_url": "https://api.github.com/users/nathanmarz/followers",
      "following_url": "https://api.github.com/users/nathanmarz/following{/other_user}",
      "gists_url": "https://api.github.com/users/nathanmarz/gists{/gist_id}",
      "starred_url": "https://api.github.com/users/nathanmarz/starred{/owner}{/repo}",
      "subscriptions_url": "https://api.github.com/users/nathanmarz/subscriptions",
      "organizations_url": "https://api.github.com/users/nathanmarz/orgs",
      "repos_url": "https://api.github.com/users/nathanmarz/repos",
      "events_url": "https://api.github.com/users/nathanmarz/events{/privacy}",
      "received_events_url": "https://api.github.com/users/nathanmarz/received_events",
      "type": "User",
      "site_admin": false
    },
    "created_at": "2015-02-18T18:06:51Z",
    "updated_at": "2015-02-18T18:06:51Z",
    "author_association": "CONTRIBUTOR",
    "body": "Nimbus only knows a worker is having trouble when it stops sending heartbeats. If a worker gets into a bad state, the worst thing to do is have it continue trying to limp along in that bad state. It should instead suicide as quickly as possible. It seems counterintuitive, but this aggressive suiciding behavior actually makes things more robust as it prevents processes from getting into weird, potentially undefined states. This has been a crucial design principle in Storm from the beginning. One consequence of it is that any crucial system thread that receives an unrecoverable exception must suicide the process rather than die quietly. \n\nFor the connection retry problem, it's a tricky situation since it may not be able to connect because the other worker is still getting set up. So the retry policy should be somehow related to the launch timeouts for worker processes specified in the configuration. Not being able to connect after the launch timeout + a certain number of attempts + a buffer period would certainly qualify as a weird state, so the process should suicide in that case. _Suiciding and restarting gets the worker back to a known state_. \n\nSo in this case, I am heavily in favor of Option 2. I don't care about killing the other tasks in the worker because this is a rare situation. It is infinitely more important to get the worker back to a known, robust state than risk leaving it in a weird state permanently.\n\nI would like to see these issues addressed as part of this patch.\n\n@miguno Thanks for the explanation on this patch's relation to backpressure  we'll handle that in a future patch.\n",
    "performed_via_github_app": null
  },

    "updated_at": "2015-02-12T08:13:44Z",
    "author_association": "CONTRIBUTOR",
    "body": "This patch allows a worker to properly detect that the connection to a peer becomes unavailable -- for whatever reason (the remote worker is dead or restarting, there was a network glitch, etc). Also, any reconnection attempts are now async so that reconnecting will not block other activities of the worker (such as sending messages to other workers it is still connected to).\n\nSo to your question: this patch includes the case of the worker that remained alive trying to (re)connect to a dead peer.\n\nDoes that help?\n",
    "performed_via_github_app": null

    "created_at": "2015-02-12T10:44:26Z",
    "updated_at": "2015-02-12T11:08:39Z",
    "author_association": "CONTRIBUTOR",
    "body": "Thanks for your feedback, Nathan.\n\nAs far as I understand this patch does not enable backpressure. But: because there is no backpressure (yet) that we can rely on, this patch will improve at least the situation during the startup phase of a topology to a) prevent that an unacked topo will lose messages during the startup, and b) we do not need to unnecessarily replay messages in case of acked topos during their startup.  This is achieved by checking that all worker connections are ready before the topology starts processing data.\n\nSo backpressure is still an open feature. Backpressure was IIRC mentioned in the initial PR because there was a deficiency (dating back to a ZMQ related TODO) that caused problems related to this PR/Storm tickets (329, 404, and one more).  However, this patch does make the best of the current situation even in the absence of backpressure.  But first and foremost this patch fixes a (critical) cascading failure that can bring Storm clusters to a halt.\n\nPlease correct me if I'm mistaken in my summary.\n",
    "performed_via_github_app": null
  },

    "created_at": "2015-02-12T20:37:55Z",
    "updated_at": "2015-02-12T20:37:55Z",
    "author_association": "CONTRIBUTOR",
    "body": "If you need at-least-once processing you must use an acking topology, which will allow Storm to replay lost messages.  If instead you go with an unacking topology (= no guaranteed message processing) then you may run into data loss.  There re pros and cons for each variant, and e.g. in our case we use both depending on the use case.\n\nAlso: The semantics described above have been in Storm right from the beginning.  None of these have been changed by this pull request.\n\n> On 12.02.2015, at 20:01, Daniel Schonfeld notifications@github.com wrote:\n> \n> Doesn't dropping the messages coming from a non ack/fail caring spout negate the 'at least once' attempt of storm? I mean doesn't that kinda force you to make all your spouts ack/fail aware where before you could have gotten away without it?\n> \n> In other words. There is a chance that if the worker that died is the one containing the spout and if the first bolt is located on another worker, that technically at-least once wasn't tried but rather fell to the floor right away.\n> \n> \n> Reply to this email directly or view it on GitHub.\n",
    "performed_via_github_app": null
  },

    "id": 74914806,
    "node_id": "MDEyOklzc3VlQ29tbWVudDc0OTE0ODA2",
    "user": {
      "login": "nathanmarz",
      "id": 131416,
      "node_id": "MDQ6VXNlcjEzMTQxNg==",
      "avatar_url": "https://avatars0.githubusercontent.com/u/131416?v=4",
      "gravatar_id": "",
      "url": "https://api.github.com/users/nathanmarz",
      "html_url": "https://github.com/nathanmarz",
      "followers_url": "https://api.github.com/users/nathanmarz/followers",
      "following_url": "https://api.github.com/users/nathanmarz/following{/other_user}",
      "gists_url": "https://api.github.com/users/nathanmarz/gists{/gist_id}",
      "starred_url": "https://api.github.com/users/nathanmarz/starred{/owner}{/repo}",
      "subscriptions_url": "https://api.github.com/users/nathanmarz/subscriptions",
      "organizations_url": "https://api.github.com/users/nathanmarz/orgs",
      "repos_url": "https://api.github.com/users/nathanmarz/repos",
      "events_url": "https://api.github.com/users/nathanmarz/events{/privacy}",
      "received_events_url": "https://api.github.com/users/nathanmarz/received_events",
      "type": "User",
      "site_admin": false
    },
    "created_at": "2015-02-18T18:06:51Z",
    "updated_at": "2015-02-18T18:06:51Z",
    "author_association": "CONTRIBUTOR",
    "body": "Nimbus only knows a worker is having trouble when it stops sending heartbeats. If a worker gets into a bad state, the worst thing to do is have it continue trying to limp along in that bad state. It should instead suicide as quickly as possible. It seems counterintuitive, but this aggressive suiciding behavior actually makes things more robust as it prevents processes from getting into weird, potentially undefined states. This has been a crucial design principle in Storm from the beginning. One consequence of it is that any crucial system thread that receives an unrecoverable exception must suicide the process rather than die quietly. \n\nFor the connection retry problem, it's a tricky situation since it may not be able to connect because the other worker is still getting set up. So the retry policy should be somehow related to the launch timeouts for worker processes specified in the configuration. Not being able to connect after the launch timeout + a certain number of attempts + a buffer period would certainly qualify as a weird state, so the process should suicide in that case. _Suiciding and restarting gets the worker back to a known state_. \n\nSo in this case, I am heavily in favor of Option 2. I don't care about killing the other tasks in the worker because this is a rare situation. It is infinitely more important to get the worker back to a known, robust state than risk leaving it in a weird state permanently.\n\nI would like to see these issues addressed as part of this patch.\n\n@miguno Thanks for the explanation on this patch's relation to backpressure  we'll handle that in a future patch.\n",
    "performed_via_github_app": null
  },

    "created_at": "2015-02-03T16:41:23Z",
    "updated_at": "2015-02-03T16:41:23Z",
    "author_association": "CONTRIBUTOR",
    "body": "For the most part it looks OK.  I am concerned about a few of the APIs seem confusing to me and could use some better javadocs.  Also I am concerned with the performance of some of the sql involved.  We are regenerating a lot of the sql from text for each query.  I am not a sql expert, but I thought that the idea behind prepared statements was that it made it so the sql engine did not have to reparse and compile the query each time.  I'm not sure how each server does that internally, but the fact that we are doing string manipulation for each query instead of once when the bolt is prepared, seems problematic.\n\nAlso the Columns magic we are doing seems OK, but like I said I am not a SQL expert and it feels like just using a stored query would be a lot simpler then all of this. \n",
    "performed_via_github_app": null
  },

    "author_association": "NONE",
    "body": "This would indeed be nice but after trying it out it seems that if a batch has more than one tuple to insert, then only the last tuple is inserted.\n\nIn [JdbcClient#insert](https://github.com/Parth-Brahmbhatt/incubator-storm/blob/STORM-616/external/storm-jdbc/src/main/java/org/apache/storm/jdbc/common/JdbcClient.java#L48) we can see that there's only one set of `VALUES` (line 61-64) but then it loops on all the columns and each one overrides the previous values that were set as SQL parameters leading to only the last one beeing used.\n",

    "author_association": "CONTRIBUTOR",
    "body": "@revans2, \nI have addressed all the concerns and all tests pass now.\n- `backtype.storm.utils-test test-new-curator-uses-exponential-backoff` exposed `getMaxRetryInterval` for testing alone. Since the `maxRetryInterval` is argument passed in constructor and need not again be retrieved for assertion against what was passed to the constructor. \n- About failing tests, the constructor arguments needed to be corrected, since old class had different order of `maxRetries` and `maxSleepTimeMs` in `Utils.java`.\n- About `divide by zero`, was scenarios I overlooked - when `maxRetries` is below `expRetriesThreshold`, making the RetryPolicy - exponential only. In that case, the calculation of `linearBaseSleepMs` failed. Now I am forcing it to `1` whenever user configures `maxRetries` below exponential retry threshold. \n",
    "performed_via_github_app": null

    "updated_at": "2016-10-23T15:32:15Z",
    "author_association": "CONTRIBUTOR",
    "body": "@jongyoul @zjffdu \nThis issue is with hadoop 2.7 only. With hadoop 2.6 making hadoop dependency as provided works well.\n\nWith Hadoop 2.7 (and only 2.7)  I get the following exception\nCaused by: java.lang.NoSuchMethodError: org.apache.hadoop.tracing.SpanReceiverHost.get(Lorg/apache/hadoop/conf/Configuration;Ljava/lang/String;)Lorg/apache/hadoop/tracing/SpanReceiverHost;\n        at org.apache.hadoop.hdfs.DFSClient.<init>(DFSClient.java:634)\n        at org.apache.hadoop.hdfs.DFSClient.<init>(DFSClient.java:619)\n        at org.apache.hadoop.hdfs.DistributedFileSystem.initialize(DistributedFileSystem.java:149)\n        at org.apache.hadoop.fs.FileSystem.createFileSystem(FileSystem.java:2596)\n        at org.apache.hadoop.fs.FileSystem.access$200(FileSystem.java:91)\n        at org.apache.hadoop.fs.FileSystem$Cache.getInternal(FileSystem.java:2630)\n        at org.apache.hadoop.fs.FileSystem$Cache.get(FileSystem.java:2612)\n        at org.apache.hadoop.fs.FileSystem.get(FileSystem.java:370)\n        at org.apache.hadoop.fs.FileSystem.get(FileSystem.java:169)\n        at org.apache.zeppelin.util.HdfsSite.mkdirs(HdfsSite.java:98)\n\nThis is probably due to the fact that even when compiling with the hadoop.2-7 profile, we still get in the zeppelin lib folder the file hadoop-common-2.6.0.jar\n",

    "author_association": "CONTRIBUTOR",
    "body": "@davidtzoor I'm not sure what you missed, your local master branch seems quite outdated. Zeppelin follows [fork & pull](https://github.com/apache/zeppelin/blob/master/CONTRIBUTING.md#source-control-workflow) model as a source control workflow. \n\n##### 1. In your forked local repository\n\n```\ngit checkout master\n```\n\n##### 2. set upstream and update local master\n\n```\ngit remote add upstream git://github.com/apache/zeppelin.git\ngit fetch upstream\ngit pull upstream master\n```\n\n##### 3. rebase your branch `forcelayout` with latest master\n\n```\ngit checkout forcelayout\ngit rebase master\n```\n\nDid you do as the above steps?\n",
    "performed_via_github_app": null
  },

    "author_association": "CONTRIBUTOR",
    "body": "@davidtzoor I'm not sure what you missed, your local master branch seems quite outdated. Zeppelin follows [fork & pull](https://github.com/apache/zeppelin/blob/master/CONTRIBUTING.md#source-control-workflow) model as a source control workflow. \n\n##### 1. In your forked local repository\n\n```\ngit checkout master\n```\n\n##### 2. set upstream and update local master\n\n```\ngit remote add upstream git://github.com/apache/zeppelin.git\ngit fetch upstream\ngit pull upstream master\n```\n\n##### 3. rebase your branch `forcelayout` with latest master\n\n```\ngit checkout forcelayout\ngit rebase master\n```\n\nDid you do as the above steps?\n",
    "performed_via_github_app": null
  },

    "author_association": "CONTRIBUTOR",
    "body": "@davidtzoor I'm not sure what you missed, your local master branch seems quite outdated. Zeppelin follows [fork & pull](https://github.com/apache/zeppelin/blob/master/CONTRIBUTING.md#source-control-workflow) model as a source control workflow. \n\n##### 1. In your forked local repository\n\n```\ngit checkout master\n```\n\n##### 2. set upstream and update local master\n\n```\ngit remote add upstream git://github.com/apache/zeppelin.git\ngit fetch upstream\ngit pull upstream master\n```\n\n##### 3. rebase your branch `forcelayout` with latest master\n\n```\ngit checkout forcelayout\ngit rebase master\n```\n\nDid you do as the above steps?\n",
    "performed_via_github_app": null
  },

    "created_at": "2016-07-05T12:50:27Z",
    "updated_at": "2016-07-05T12:50:27Z",
    "author_association": "CONTRIBUTOR",
    "body": "@davidtzoor I'm not sure what you missed, your local master branch seems quite outdated. Zeppelin follows [fork & pull](https://github.com/apache/zeppelin/blob/master/CONTRIBUTING.md#source-control-workflow) model as a source control workflow. \n\n##### 1. In your forked local repository\n\n```\ngit checkout master\n```\n\n##### 2. set upstream and update local master\n\n```\ngit remote add upstream git://github.com/apache/zeppelin.git\ngit fetch upstream\ngit pull upstream master\n```\n\n##### 3. rebase your branch `forcelayout` with latest master\n\n```\ngit checkout forcelayout\ngit rebase master\n```\n\nDid you do as the above steps?\n",
    "performed_via_github_app": null
  },
  {
    "url": "https://api.github.com/repos/apache/zeppelin/issues/comments/230468963",
    "html_url": "https://github.com/apache/zeppelin/pull/1044#issuecomment-230468963",
    "issue_url": "https://api.github.com/repos/apache/zeppelin/issues/1044",
    "id": 230468963,

    "author_association": "CONTRIBUTOR",
    "body": "@davidtzoor I'm not sure what you missed, your local master branch seems quite outdated. Zeppelin follows [fork & pull](https://github.com/apache/zeppelin/blob/master/CONTRIBUTING.md#source-control-workflow) model as a source control workflow. \n\n##### 1. In your forked local repository\n\n```\ngit checkout master\n```\n\n##### 2. set upstream and update local master\n\n```\ngit remote add upstream git://github.com/apache/zeppelin.git\ngit fetch upstream\ngit pull upstream master\n```\n\n##### 3. rebase your branch `forcelayout` with latest master\n\n```\ngit checkout forcelayout\ngit rebase master\n```\n\nDid you do as the above steps?\n",
    "performed_via_github_app": null
  },

    "author_association": "CONTRIBUTOR",
    "body": "@davidtzoor I'm not sure what you missed, your local master branch seems quite outdated. Zeppelin follows [fork & pull](https://github.com/apache/zeppelin/blob/master/CONTRIBUTING.md#source-control-workflow) model as a source control workflow. \n\n##### 1. In your forked local repository\n\n```\ngit checkout master\n```\n\n##### 2. set upstream and update local master\n\n```\ngit remote add upstream git://github.com/apache/zeppelin.git\ngit fetch upstream\ngit pull upstream master\n```\n\n##### 3. rebase your branch `forcelayout` with latest master\n\n```\ngit checkout forcelayout\ngit rebase master\n```\n\nDid you do as the above steps?\n",
    "performed_via_github_app": null
  },

    "author_association": "CONTRIBUTOR",
    "body": "@davidtzoor I'm not sure what you missed, your local master branch seems quite outdated. Zeppelin follows [fork & pull](https://github.com/apache/zeppelin/blob/master/CONTRIBUTING.md#source-control-workflow) model as a source control workflow. \n\n##### 1. In your forked local repository\n\n```\ngit checkout master\n```\n\n##### 2. set upstream and update local master\n\n```\ngit remote add upstream git://github.com/apache/zeppelin.git\ngit fetch upstream\ngit pull upstream master\n```\n\n##### 3. rebase your branch `forcelayout` with latest master\n\n```\ngit checkout forcelayout\ngit rebase master\n```\n\nDid you do as the above steps?\n",
    "performed_via_github_app": null
  },

    "author_association": "CONTRIBUTOR",
    "body": "@davidtzoor I'm not sure what you missed, your local master branch seems quite outdated. Zeppelin follows [fork & pull](https://github.com/apache/zeppelin/blob/master/CONTRIBUTING.md#source-control-workflow) model as a source control workflow. \n\n##### 1. In your forked local repository\n\n```\ngit checkout master\n```\n\n##### 2. set upstream and update local master\n\n```\ngit remote add upstream git://github.com/apache/zeppelin.git\ngit fetch upstream\ngit pull upstream master\n```\n\n##### 3. rebase your branch `forcelayout` with latest master\n\n```\ngit checkout forcelayout\ngit rebase master\n```\n\nDid you do as the above steps?\n",
    "performed_via_github_app": null
  },

    "updated_at": "2016-07-05T12:50:27Z",
    "author_association": "CONTRIBUTOR",
    "body": "@davidtzoor I'm not sure what you missed, your local master branch seems quite outdated. Zeppelin follows [fork & pull](https://github.com/apache/zeppelin/blob/master/CONTRIBUTING.md#source-control-workflow) model as a source control workflow. \n\n##### 1. In your forked local repository\n\n```\ngit checkout master\n```\n\n##### 2. set upstream and update local master\n\n```\ngit remote add upstream git://github.com/apache/zeppelin.git\ngit fetch upstream\ngit pull upstream master\n```\n\n##### 3. rebase your branch `forcelayout` with latest master\n\n```\ngit checkout forcelayout\ngit rebase master\n```\n\nDid you do as the above steps?\n",
    "performed_via_github_app": null
  },
  {

    "author_association": "MEMBER",
    "body": "I think `mvn package -Pbuild-distr -Pspark-1.5 -Phadoop-2.3 -Ppyspark -Pscalding -Pgeode -B` skip tests because of we defined [`-Pbuild-distr` to do so](https://github.com/apache/incubator-zeppelin/blob/master/pom.xml#L648).\n\n[Line 35](https://github.com/apache/incubator-zeppelin/blob/master/.travis.yml#L35) will run actual test. If we put -Pgeode in this line, it'll fail while ZEPPELIN-375 is not resolved.\n\nI think this PR make sure geode module is able to build (without test).\nit looks good to me.\n",
    "performed_via_github_app": null

    "body": ">> If using Spring bootRun, I think this is normal since it is not compiled to javascript until run in the browser for debugging.\r\n\r\n>It is bootRun. The bootRun step is wired to do a buildDev that will include source maps and metadata so errors found during dev can be linked directly to the TypeScript source.  The console warning is just to let you know it is a dev build.  Building a war will compile with --prod and all code will be compiled fully to javascript and optimized and this warning will not appear in the console. \r\n",

    "author_association": "CONTRIBUTOR",
    "body": "In looking at the changes to this PR that have been made this week, there are still some issues. I had several build issues when pulling down the latest updates. They seemed to be the npm cache and npm install scripts in Gradle. I don't know if it was an issue with downloading packages, as each build error did not reproduce after running again. At this time, this PR is a bit unstable given the amount of updates and fixes required to get it stable. I recommend creating a new branch with these new changes, applying them and doing a thorough developer test to validate all screens are working, all functionality is working, and the styling is consistent with the Apereo master branch before submitting the pull request. If you have any questions regarding my request, feel free to email me jmuramoto|at|unicon|dot|net.",

    "body": "Ah yes.  My last commit before needed some changes to test code and a small compile error was introduced that stopped the ng build --prod from succeeding.  Those issues should be fixed with the latest push and hopefully you can build now.\r\n\r\nIf a feature branch works best or makes it easier for everyone to work on these changes, that is fine by me.\r\n\r\nHere are some things to consider for this PR and planned features:\r\n\r\n- Things that need to be looked at closely is functionality that required JQuery in the original screens.  We need to either find a way to integrate JQuery back in or retool the components that relied on it.  Right now I think the SAML2 screen is not fully functional.\r\n\r\n- I am not completely happy with the up and down arrows that I came up with for ordering services, but I wasn't a big fan of the DnD that was there before either.\r\n\r\n- Dates right now are reliant on the HTML5 browsers for Datepicker functionality, so older browsers are not fully supported.  \r\n\r\n- A scrollable Tab bar would also be ideal.\r\n\r\nFor the UI isuues above, ultimately I would like to move on to using these: https://material.angular.io/components\r\n\r\nThe recently added Datatable and the Datepicker are nice additions and the srolling Tab bar looks great too. \r\n\r\nSince we have made the DomainServicesManager the default in CAS it may make sense to add the Domain screen with this PR, since that is how the services are accessed by CAS now.  Everything still works as expected with just the Services screen though and it could be introduced in a later PR.\r\n\r\nThe JSON Payload refactor I think could be done as part of this merge or a separate PR later.  ",

The bootRun step is wired to do a buildDev that will include source maps and metadata so errors found during dev can be linked directly to the TypeScript source.  The console warning is just to let you know it is a dev build.  Building a war will compile with --prod and all code will be compiled fully to javascript and optimized and this warning will not appear in the console. \r\n",

    "author_association": "CONTRIBUTOR",
    "body": "Ah yes.  My last commit before needed some changes to test code and a small compile error was introduced that stopped the ng build --prod from succeeding.  Those issues should be fixed with the latest push and hopefully you can build now.\r\n\r\nIf a feature branch works best or makes it easier for everyone to work on these changes, that is fine by me.\r\n\r\nHere are some things to consider for this PR and planned features:\r\n\r\n- Things that need to be looked at closely is functionality that required JQuery in the original screens.  We need to either find a way to integrate JQuery back in or retool the components that relied on it.  Right now I think the SAML2 screen is not fully functional.\r\n\r\n- I am not completely happy with the up and down arrows that I came up with for ordering services, but I wasn't a big fan of the DnD that was there before either.\r\n\r\n- Dates right now are reliant on the HTML5 browsers for Datepicker functionality, so older browsers are not fully supported.  \r\n\r\n- A scrollable Tab bar would also be ideal.\r\n\r\nFor the UI isuues above, ultimately I would like to move on to using these: https://material.angular.io/components\r\n\r\nThe recently added Datatable and the Datepicker are nice additions and the srolling Tab bar looks great too. \r\n\r\nSince we have made the DomainServicesManager the default in CAS it may make sense to add the Domain screen with this PR, since that is how the services are accessed by CAS now.  Everything still works as expected with just the Services screen though and it could be introduced in a later PR.\r\n\r\nThe JSON Payload refactor I think could be done as part of this merge or a separate PR later.  ",

    "body": ">> If using Spring bootRun, I think this is normal since it is not compiled to javascript until run in the browser for debugging.\r\n\r\n>It is bootRun. Majority of development happens via bootRun and it would be great to make it all consistent with no exceptions.\r\n\r\nI am confused as to what the issue is.  The bootRun step is wired to do a buildDev that will include source maps and metadata so errors found during dev can be linked directly to the TypeScript source.  The console warning is just to let you know it is a dev build.  Building a war will compile with --prod and all code will be compiled fully to javascript and optimized and this warning will not appear in the console. \r\n",

    "created_at": "2017-07-27T20:17:03Z",
    "updated_at": "2017-07-27T20:17:03Z",
    "author_association": "CONTRIBUTOR",
    "body": "Ah yes.  My last commit before needed some changes to test code and a small compile error was introduced that stopped the ng build --prod from succeeding.  Those issues should be fixed with the latest push and hopefully you can build now.\r\n\r\nIf a feature branch works best or makes it easier for everyone to work on these changes, that is fine by me.\r\n\r\nHere are some things to consider for this PR and planned features:\r\n\r\n- Things that need to be looked at closely is functionality that required JQuery in the original screens.  We need to either find a way to integrate JQuery back in or retool the components that relied on it.  Right now I think the SAML2 screen is not fully functional.\r\n\r\n- I am not completely happy with the up and down arrows that I came up with for ordering services, but I wasn't a big fan of the DnD that was there before either.\r\n\r\n- Dates right now are reliant on the HTML5 browsers for Datepicker functionality, so older browsers are not fully supported.  \r\n\r\n- A scrollable Tab bar would also be ideal.\r\n\r\nFor the UI isuues above, ultimately I would like to move on to using these: https://material.angular.io/components\r\n\r\nThe recently added Datatable and the Datepicker are nice additions and the srolling Tab bar looks great too. \r\n\r\nSince we have made the DomainServicesManager the default in CAS it may make sense to add the Domain screen with this PR, since that is how the services are accessed by CAS now.  Everything still works as expected with just the Services screen though and it could be introduced in a later PR.\r\n\r\nThe JSON Payload refactor I think could be done as part of this merge or a separate PR later.  ",
    "performed_via_github_app": null

Could we perhaps integrate and wire that step into the build so it works for all cases? Majority of development happens via bootRun and it would be great to make it all consistent with no exceptions.\r\n\r\nI am confused as to what the issue is.  The bootRun step is wired to do a buildDev that will include source maps and metadata so errors found during dev can be linked directly to the TypeScript source.  The console warning is just to let you know it is a dev build.  Building a war will compile with --prod and all code will be compiled fully to javascript and optimized and this warning will not appear in the console. \r\n",

    "author_association": "CONTRIBUTOR",
    "body": ">> If using Spring bootRun, I think this is normal since it is not compiled to javascript until run in the browser for debugging.\r\n\r\n>It is bootRun. Could we perhaps integrate and wire that step into the build so it works for all cases? Majority of development happens via bootRun and it would be great to make it all consistent with no exceptions.\r\n\r\nI am confused as to what the issue is.  The bootRun step is wired to do a buildDev that will include source maps and metadata so errors found during dev can be linked directly to the TypeScript source.  The console warning is just to let you know it is a dev build.  Building a war will compile with --prod and all code will be compiled fully to javascript and optimized and this warning will not appear in the console. \r\n",
    "performed_via_github_app": null

Those issues should be fixed with the latest push and hopefully you can build now.\r\n\r\nIf a feature branch works best or makes it easier for everyone to work on these changes, that is fine by me.\r\n\r\nHere are some things to consider for this PR and planned features:\r\n\r\n- Things that need to be looked at closely is functionality that required JQuery in the original screens.  We need to either find a way to integrate JQuery back in or retool the components that relied on it.  Right now I think the SAML2 screen is not fully functional.\r\n\r\n- I am not completely happy with the up and down arrows that I came up with for ordering services, but I wasn't a big fan of the DnD that was there before either.\r\n\r\n- Dates right now are reliant on the HTML5 browsers for Datepicker functionality, so older browsers are not fully supported.  \r\n\r\n- A scrollable Tab bar would also be ideal.\r\n\r\nFor the UI isuues above, ultimately I would like to move on to using these: https://material.angular.io/components\r\n\r\nThe recently added Datatable and the Datepicker are nice additions and the srolling Tab bar looks great too. \r\n\r\nSince we have made the DomainServicesManager the default in CAS it may make sense to add the Domain screen with this PR, since that is how the services are accessed by CAS now.  Everything still works as expected with just the Services screen though and it could be introduced in a later PR.\r\n\r\nThe JSON Payload refactor I think could be done as part of this merge or a separate PR later.     "author_association": "CONTRIBUTOR",
    "body": ">> If using Spring bootRun, I think this is normal since it is not compiled to javascript until run in the browser for debugging.\r\n\r\n>It is bootRun. Could we perhaps integrate and wire that step into the build so it works for all cases? Majority of development happens via bootRun and it would be great to make it all consistent with no exceptions.\r\n\r\nI am confused as to what the issue is.  The bootRun step is wired to do a buildDev that will include source maps and metadata so errors found during dev can be linked directly to the TypeScript source.  The console warning is just to let you know it is a dev build.  Building a war will compile with --prod and all code will be compiled fully to javascript and optimized and this warning will not appear in the console. \r\n",

    "body": "Ah yes.  My last commit before needed some changes to test code and a small compile error was introduced that stopped the ng build --prod from succeeding.  Those issues should be fixed with the latest push and hopefully you can build now.\r\n\r\nIf a feature branch works best or makes it easier for everyone to work on these changes, that is fine by me.\r\n\r\nHere are some things to consider for this PR and planned features:\r\n\r\n- Things that need to be looked at closely is functionality that required JQuery in the original screens.  We need to either find a way to integrate JQuery back in or retool the components that relied on it.  Right now I think the SAML2 screen is not fully functional.\r\n\r\n- I am not completely happy with the up and down arrows that I came up with for ordering services, but I wasn't a big fan of the DnD that was there before either.\r\n\r\n- Dates right now are reliant on the HTML5 browsers for Datepicker functionality, so older browsers are not fully supported.  \r\n\r\n- A scrollable Tab bar would also be ideal.\r\n\r\nFor the UI isuues above, ultimately I would like to move on to using these: https://material.angular.io/components\r\n\r\nThe recently added Datatable and the Datepicker are nice additions and the srolling Tab bar looks great too. \r\n\r\nSince we have made the DomainServicesManager the default in CAS it may make sense to add the Domain screen with this PR, since that is how the services are accessed by CAS now.  Everything still works as expected with just the Services screen though and it could be introduced in a later PR.\r\n\r\nThe JSON Payload refactor I think could be done as part of this merge or a separate PR later.     "body": ">> If using Spring bootRun, I think this is normal since it is not compiled to javascript until run in the browser for debugging.\r\n\r\n>It is bootRun. Majority of development happens via bootRun and it would be great to make it all consistent with no exceptions.\r\n\r\nI am confused as to what the issue is.  The bootRun step is wired to do a buildDev that will include source maps and metadata so errors found during dev can be linked directly to the TypeScript source.  The console warning is just to let you know it is a dev build.  Building a war will compile with --prod and all code will be compiled fully to javascript and optimized and this warning will not appear in the console. \r\n",

    "body": "Ah yes.  My last commit before needed some changes to test code and a small compile error was introduced that stopped the ng build --prod from succeeding.  Those issues should be fixed with the latest push and hopefully you can build now.\r\n\r\nIf a feature branch works best or makes it easier for everyone to work on these changes, that is fine by me.\r\n\r\nHere are some things to consider for this PR and planned features:\r\n\r\n- Things that need to be looked at closely is functionality that required JQuery in the original screens.  We need to either find a way to integrate JQuery back in or retool the components that relied on it.  Right now I think the SAML2 screen is not fully functional.\r\n\r\n- I am not completely happy with the up and down arrows that I came up with for ordering services, but I wasn't a big fan of the DnD that was there before either.\r\n\r\n- Dates right now are reliant on the HTML5 browsers for Datepicker functionality, so older browsers are not fully supported.  \r\n\r\n- A scrollable Tab bar would also be ideal.\r\n\r\nFor the UI isuues above, ultimately I would like to move on to using these: https://material.angular.io/components\r\n\r\nThe recently added Datatable and the Datepicker are nice additions and the srolling Tab bar looks great too. \r\n\r\nSince we have made the DomainServicesManager the default in CAS it may make sense to add the Domain screen with this PR, since that is how the services are accessed by CAS now.  Everything still works as expected with just the Services screen though and it could be introduced in a later PR.\r\n\r\nThe JSON Payload refactor I think could be done as part of this merge or a separate PR later. The bootRun step is wired to do a buildDev that will include source maps and metadata so errors found during dev can be linked directly to the TypeScript source.  The console warning is just to let you know it is a dev build.  Building a war will compile with --prod and all code will be compiled fully to javascript and optimized and this warning will not appear in the console. \r\n",

Sorry to be thick about this, but are you saying it should compile with --prod so it is the same as building for a war?\r\n\r\nYes exactly; Are there any drawbacks to this approach? If I understand correctly, running with --prod does minify and obfuscate javascript which might not be ideal for dev. Is that the only issue? I realize I did originally ask for this, thinking it's a required thing for the \"SAML2 Provider service Type\" changes but if the latter is fixed and the two are now irrelevant, we might safely ignore my objection. \r\n\r\n>Keep the bugs coming and also let me know if there are any over all design/layout/architecture changes that would improve the PR.\r\n\r\nVery much appreciate it. One thing I have spoken to Jeff and Jodie about is that perhaps we might take this chance to rethink the JSON payload that is submitted to the backend. It's very cryptic and confusing at this point and I very much dislike the backend implementation of mappings and parsings. I could very much use your help on either front to work with others to make sure as this area grows larger, it continues to be maintainable. The RegisteredService model is only going to but grow and we must make sure either front is amenable to future changes without resorting to ugly hacks here and there.",

We need to either find a way to integrate JQuery back in or retool the components that relied on it.  Right now I think the SAML2 screen is not fully functional.\r\n\r\n- I am not completely happy with the up and down arrows that I came up with for ordering services, but I wasn't a big fan of the DnD that was there before either.\r\n\r\n- Dates right now are reliant on the HTML5 browsers for Datepicker functionality, so older browsers are not fully supported.  \r\n\r\n- A scrollable Tab bar would also be ideal.\r\n\r\nFor the UI isuues above, ultimately I would like to move on to using these: https://material.angular.io/components\r\n\r\nThe recently added Datatable and the Datepicker are nice additions and the srolling Tab bar looks great too. \r\n\r\nSince we have made the DomainServicesManager the default in CAS it may make sense to add the Domain screen with this PR, since that is how the services are accessed by CAS now.  Everything still works as expected with just the Services screen though and it could be introduced in a later PR.\r\n\r\nThe JSON Payload refactor I think could be done as part of this merge or a separate PR later.     "body": "@varunnvs92 I disagree - my changes are non-breaking. If the method body is changed to swap the usages of the parameters but the names of parameters are not changed, that _will_ be a breaking change.\n\nAll I did was rename the parameters; I didn't change how they are used. Both before and after my changes, the first `Date` was and is used to populate the `DateLessThan` in the policy and the second `Date` was and is used to populate the `DateGreaterThan` in the policy.\n\nIf there was test coverage of the existing code, I expect that the test would continue to pass with these changes without modification of the test.\n",

    "author_association": "CONTRIBUTOR",
    "body": "@mhurne \nAssume a customer who wants to set the activeFrom value as 1000 and expiresOn value as 2000. Currently he would be using this (String resourcePath, Date activeFrom, Date expiresOn, String ipAddress) method as (resource, 1000, 2000, ip). Now if we change the method signature as (String resourcePath, Date expiresOn, Date activeFrom, String ipAddress), the customer's code which is (resource, 1000, 2000, ip) seems like he is using 1000 for expiresOn and 2000 for activeFrom which is breaking change/confuses the customer.\n\nI know that the your implementation works good for new customers but may confuse customers already using this function. I agree that the current code has bug and doesn't work as expected. So fixing the body should be good.\n",

    "created_at": "2016-05-02T23:34:11Z",
    "updated_at": "2016-05-02T23:34:11Z",
    "author_association": "CONTRIBUTOR",
    "body": "@varunnvs92 The thing is, the meaning of the current `activeFrom` parameter is actually `expiresOn` and vice-versa. My changes don't change the way the parameters are used, it just fixes the names. In your example, `DateLessThan` will be based on `1000` and `DateGreaterThan` will be based on `2000`. That doesn't make any sense, and is exactly the issue I ran into that led to these changes...I was able to get the method to behave the way I wanted by pretending that `activeFrom` was actually named `expiresOn` and vice-versa. This changeset just fixes the names. If the parameters didn't have names, this changeset wouldn't be needed. I don't know how else to clarify this. I literally did a \"Refactor->Rename\" in IntelliJ for each parameter. I didn't simply swap the parameters in the signature, I renamed them in both the signature and the method body to ensure that their behavior did not change.\n\nPerhaps we should add a test around the existing implementation, merge that in to master first, and then merge that test in to my fork/branch. If we do that, I'm confident the test will continue to pass without needing to change here.\n",
    "performed_via_github_app": null
  },

    "created_at": "2016-05-02T22:33:00Z",
    "updated_at": "2016-05-02T22:33:00Z",
    "author_association": "CONTRIBUTOR",
    "body": "@mhurne \nAssume a customer who wants to set the activeFrom value as 1000 and expiresOn value as 2000. Currently he would be using this (String resourcePath, Date activeFrom, Date expiresOn, String ipAddress) method as (resource, 1000, 2000, ip). Now if we change the method signature as (String resourcePath, Date expiresOn, Date activeFrom, String ipAddress), the customer's code which is (resource, 1000, 2000, ip) seems like he is using 1000 for expiresOn and 2000 for activeFrom which is breaking change/confuses the customer.\n\nI know that the your implementation works good for new customers but may confuse customers already using this function. I agree that the current code has bug and doesn't work as expected. So fixing the body should be good.\n",
    "performed_via_github_app": null

    "created_at": "2016-05-02T23:34:11Z",
    "updated_at": "2016-05-02T23:34:11Z",
    "author_association": "CONTRIBUTOR",
    "body": "@varunnvs92 The thing is, the meaning of the current `activeFrom` parameter is actually `expiresOn` and vice-versa. My changes don't change the way the parameters are used, it just fixes the names. In your example, `DateLessThan` will be based on `1000` and `DateGreaterThan` will be based on `2000`. That doesn't make any sense, and is exactly the issue I ran into that led to these changes...I was able to get the method to behave the way I wanted by pretending that `activeFrom` was actually named `expiresOn` and vice-versa. This changeset just fixes the names. If the parameters didn't have names, this changeset wouldn't be needed. I don't know how else to clarify this. I literally did a \"Refactor->Rename\" in IntelliJ for each parameter. I didn't simply swap the parameters in the signature, I renamed them in both the signature and the method body to ensure that their behavior did not change.\n\nPerhaps we should add a test around the existing implementation, merge that in to master first, and then merge that test in to my fork/branch. If we do that, I'm confident the test will continue to pass without needing to change here.\n",
    "performed_via_github_app": null
  },

    "author_association": "CONTRIBUTOR",
    "body": "@varunnvs92 I disagree - my changes are non-breaking. If the method body is changed to swap the usages of the parameters but the names of parameters are not changed, that _will_ be a breaking change.\n\nAll I did was rename the parameters; I didn't change how they are used. Both before and after my changes, the first `Date` was and is used to populate the `DateLessThan` in the policy and the second `Date` was and is used to populate the `DateGreaterThan` in the policy.\n\nIf there was test coverage of the existing code, I expect that the test would continue to pass with these changes without modification of the test.\n",

    "updated_at": "2016-05-02T22:33:00Z",
    "author_association": "CONTRIBUTOR",
    "body": "@mhurne \nAssume a customer who wants to set the activeFrom value as 1000 and expiresOn value as 2000. Currently he would be using this (String resourcePath, Date activeFrom, Date expiresOn, String ipAddress) method as (resource, 1000, 2000, ip). Now if we change the method signature as (String resourcePath, Date expiresOn, Date activeFrom, String ipAddress), the customer's code which is (resource, 1000, 2000, ip) seems like he is using 1000 for expiresOn and 2000 for activeFrom which is breaking change/confuses the customer.\n\nI know that the your implementation works good for new customers but may confuse customers already using this function. I agree that the current code has bug and doesn't work as expected. So fixing the body should be good.\n",

      "site_admin": false
    },
    "created_at": "2016-05-02T23:34:11Z",
    "updated_at": "2016-05-02T23:34:11Z",
    "author_association": "CONTRIBUTOR",
    "body": "@varunnvs92 The thing is, the meaning of the current `activeFrom` parameter is actually `expiresOn` and vice-versa. My changes don't change the way the parameters are used, it just fixes the names. In your example, `DateLessThan` will be based on `1000` and `DateGreaterThan` will be based on `2000`. That doesn't make any sense, and is exactly the issue I ran into that led to these changes...I was able to get the method to behave the way I wanted by pretending that `activeFrom` was actually named `expiresOn` and vice-versa. This changeset just fixes the names. If the parameters didn't have names, this changeset wouldn't be needed. I don't know how else to clarify this. I literally did a \"Refactor->Rename\" in IntelliJ for each parameter. I didn't simply swap the parameters in the signature, I renamed them in both the signature and the method body to ensure that their behavior did not change.\n\nPerhaps we should add a test around the existing implementation, merge that in to master first, and then merge that test in to my fork/branch. If we do that, I'm confident the test will continue to pass without needing to change here.\n",
    "performed_via_github_app": null
  },

    "body": "@varunnvs92 I disagree - my changes are non-breaking. Both before and after my changes, the first `Date` was and is used to populate the `DateLessThan` in the policy and the second `Date` was and is used to populate the `DateGreaterThan` in the policy.\n\nIf there was test coverage of the existing code, I expect that the test would continue to pass with these changes without modification of the test.\n",

    "author_association": "CONTRIBUTOR",
    "body": "@mhurne \nAssume a customer who wants to set the activeFrom value as 1000 and expiresOn value as 2000. Currently he would be using this (String resourcePath, Date activeFrom, Date expiresOn, String ipAddress) method as (resource, 1000, 2000, ip). Now if we change the method signature as (String resourcePath, Date expiresOn, Date activeFrom, String ipAddress), the customer's code which is (resource, 1000, 2000, ip) seems like he is using 1000 for expiresOn and 2000 for activeFrom which is breaking change/confuses the customer.\n\nI know that the your implementation works good for new customers but may confuse customers already using this function. I agree that the current code has bug and doesn't work as expected. So fixing the body should be good.\n",

    "created_at": "2016-05-02T23:34:11Z",
    "updated_at": "2016-05-02T23:34:11Z",
    "author_association": "CONTRIBUTOR",
    "body": "@varunnvs92 The thing is, the meaning of the current `activeFrom` parameter is actually `expiresOn` and vice-versa. My changes don't change the way the parameters are used, it just fixes the names. In your example, `DateLessThan` will be based on `1000` and `DateGreaterThan` will be based on `2000`. That doesn't make any sense, and is exactly the issue I ran into that led to these changes...I was able to get the method to behave the way I wanted by pretending that `activeFrom` was actually named `expiresOn` and vice-versa. This changeset just fixes the names. If the parameters didn't have names, this changeset wouldn't be needed. I don't know how else to clarify this. I literally did a \"Refactor->Rename\" in IntelliJ for each parameter. I didn't simply swap the parameters in the signature, I renamed them in both the signature and the method body to ensure that their behavior did not change.\n\nPerhaps we should add a test around the existing implementation, merge that in to master first, and then merge that test in to my fork/branch. If we do that, I'm confident the test will continue to pass without needing to change here.\n",
    "performed_via_github_app": null
  },

    "body": "@varunnvs92 I disagree - my changes are non-breaking. Both before and after my changes, the first `Date` was and is used to populate the `DateLessThan` in the policy and the second `Date` was and is used to populate the `DateGreaterThan` in the policy.\n\nIf there was test coverage of the existing code, I expect that the test would continue to pass with these changes without modification of the test.\n",

    "author_association": "CONTRIBUTOR",
    "body": "@mhurne \nAssume a customer who wants to set the activeFrom value as 1000 and expiresOn value as 2000. Currently he would be using this (String resourcePath, Date activeFrom, Date expiresOn, String ipAddress) method as (resource, 1000, 2000, ip). Now if we change the method signature as (String resourcePath, Date expiresOn, Date activeFrom, String ipAddress), the customer's code which is (resource, 1000, 2000, ip) seems like he is using 1000 for expiresOn and 2000 for activeFrom which is breaking change/confuses the customer.\n\nI know that the your implementation works good for new customers but may confuse customers already using this function. I agree that the current code has bug and doesn't work as expected. So fixing the body should be good.\n",

    "created_at": "2016-05-02T23:34:11Z",
    "updated_at": "2016-05-02T23:34:11Z",
    "author_association": "CONTRIBUTOR",
    "body": "@varunnvs92 The thing is, the meaning of the current `activeFrom` parameter is actually `expiresOn` and vice-versa. My changes don't change the way the parameters are used, it just fixes the names. In your example, `DateLessThan` will be based on `1000` and `DateGreaterThan` will be based on `2000`. That doesn't make any sense, and is exactly the issue I ran into that led to these changes...I was able to get the method to behave the way I wanted by pretending that `activeFrom` was actually named `expiresOn` and vice-versa. This changeset just fixes the names. If the parameters didn't have names, this changeset wouldn't be needed. I don't know how else to clarify this. I literally did a \"Refactor->Rename\" in IntelliJ for each parameter. I didn't simply swap the parameters in the signature, I renamed them in both the signature and the method body to ensure that their behavior did not change.\n\nPerhaps we should add a test around the existing implementation, merge that in to master first, and then merge that test in to my fork/branch. If we do that, I'm confident the test will continue to pass without needing to change here.\n",
    "performed_via_github_app": null
  },

    "author_association": "CONTRIBUTOR",
    "body": "@mhurne \nAssume a customer who wants to set the activeFrom value as 1000 and expiresOn value as 2000. Currently he would be using this (String resourcePath, Date activeFrom, Date expiresOn, String ipAddress) method as (resource, 1000, 2000, ip). Now if we change the method signature as (String resourcePath, Date expiresOn, Date activeFrom, String ipAddress), the customer's code which is (resource, 1000, 2000, ip) seems like he is using 1000 for expiresOn and 2000 for activeFrom which is breaking change/confuses the customer.\n\nI know that the your implementation works good for new customers but may confuse customers already using this function. I agree that the current code has bug and doesn't work as expected. So fixing the body should be good.\n",

    "created_at": "2016-05-02T23:34:11Z",
    "updated_at": "2016-05-02T23:34:11Z",
    "author_association": "CONTRIBUTOR",
    "body": "@varunnvs92 The thing is, the meaning of the current `activeFrom` parameter is actually `expiresOn` and vice-versa. My changes don't change the way the parameters are used, it just fixes the names. In your example, `DateLessThan` will be based on `1000` and `DateGreaterThan` will be based on `2000`. That doesn't make any sense, and is exactly the issue I ran into that led to these changes...I was able to get the method to behave the way I wanted by pretending that `activeFrom` was actually named `expiresOn` and vice-versa. This changeset just fixes the names. If the parameters didn't have names, this changeset wouldn't be needed. I don't know how else to clarify this. I literally did a \"Refactor->Rename\" in IntelliJ for each parameter. I didn't simply swap the parameters in the signature, I renamed them in both the signature and the method body to ensure that their behavior did not change.\n\nPerhaps we should add a test around the existing implementation, merge that in to master first, and then merge that test in to my fork/branch. If we do that, I'm confident the test will continue to pass without needing to change here.\n",
    "performed_via_github_app": null
  },

    "updated_at": "2016-05-02T22:33:00Z",
    "author_association": "CONTRIBUTOR",
    "body": "@mhurne \nAssume a customer who wants to set the activeFrom value as 1000 and expiresOn value as 2000. Currently he would be using this (String resourcePath, Date activeFrom, Date expiresOn, String ipAddress) method as (resource, 1000, 2000, ip). Now if we change the method signature as (String resourcePath, Date expiresOn, Date activeFrom, String ipAddress), the customer's code which is (resource, 1000, 2000, ip) seems like he is using 1000 for expiresOn and 2000 for activeFrom which is breaking change/confuses the customer.\n\nI know that the your implementation works good for new customers but may confuse customers already using this function. I agree that the current code has bug and doesn't work as expected. So fixing the body should be good.\n",

    "created_at": "2016-05-02T23:34:11Z",
    "updated_at": "2016-05-02T23:34:11Z",
    "author_association": "CONTRIBUTOR",
    "body": "@varunnvs92 The thing is, the meaning of the current `activeFrom` parameter is actually `expiresOn` and vice-versa. My changes don't change the way the parameters are used, it just fixes the names. In your example, `DateLessThan` will be based on `1000` and `DateGreaterThan` will be based on `2000`. That doesn't make any sense, and is exactly the issue I ran into that led to these changes...I was able to get the method to behave the way I wanted by pretending that `activeFrom` was actually named `expiresOn` and vice-versa. This changeset just fixes the names. If the parameters didn't have names, this changeset wouldn't be needed. I don't know how else to clarify this. I literally did a \"Refactor->Rename\" in IntelliJ for each parameter. I didn't simply swap the parameters in the signature, I renamed them in both the signature and the method body to ensure that their behavior did not change.\n\nPerhaps we should add a test around the existing implementation, merge that in to master first, and then merge that test in to my fork/branch. If we do that, I'm confident the test will continue to pass without needing to change here.\n",
    "performed_via_github_app": null
  },

    "author_association": "CONTRIBUTOR",
    "body": "@varunnvs92 The thing is, the meaning of the current `activeFrom` parameter is actually `expiresOn` and vice-versa. My changes don't change the way the parameters are used, it just fixes the names. In your example, `DateLessThan` will be based on `1000` and `DateGreaterThan` will be based on `2000`. That doesn't make any sense, and is exactly the issue I ran into that led to these changes...I was able to get the method to behave the way I wanted by pretending that `activeFrom` was actually named `expiresOn` and vice-versa. This changeset just fixes the names. If the parameters didn't have names, this changeset wouldn't be needed. I don't know how else to clarify this. I literally did a \"Refactor->Rename\" in IntelliJ for each parameter. I didn't simply swap the parameters in the signature, I renamed them in both the signature and the method body to ensure that their behavior did not change.\n\nPerhaps we should add a test around the existing implementation, merge that in to master first, and then merge that test in to my fork/branch. If we do that, I'm confident the test will continue to pass without needing to change here.\n",
    "performed_via_github_app": null
  },

Now if we change the method signature as (String resourcePath, Date expiresOn, Date activeFrom, String ipAddress), the customer's code which is (resource, 1000, 2000, ip) seems like he is using 1000 for expiresOn and 2000 for activeFrom which is breaking change/confuses the customer.\n\nI know that the your implementation works good for new customers but may confuse customers already using this function.     "body": "@varunnvs92 I disagree - my changes are non-breaking. Both before and after my changes, the first `Date` was and is used to populate the `DateLessThan` in the policy and the second `Date` was and is used to populate the `DateGreaterThan` in the policy.\n\nIf there was test coverage of the existing code, I expect that the test would continue to pass with these changes without modification of the test.\n",

    "author_association": "CONTRIBUTOR",
    "body": "@mhurne \nAssume a customer who wants to set the activeFrom value as 1000 and expiresOn value as 2000. Currently he would be using this (String resourcePath, Date activeFrom, Date expiresOn, String ipAddress) method as (resource, 1000, 2000, ip). Now if we change the method signature as (String resourcePath, Date expiresOn, Date activeFrom, String ipAddress), the customer's code which is (resource, 1000, 2000, ip) seems like he is using 1000 for expiresOn and 2000 for activeFrom which is breaking change/confuses the customer.\n\nI know that the your implementation works good for new customers but may confuse customers already using this function. I agree that the current code has bug and doesn't work as expected. So fixing the body should be good.\n",

      "site_admin": false
    },
    "created_at": "2016-05-02T23:34:11Z",
    "updated_at": "2016-05-02T23:34:11Z",
    "author_association": "CONTRIBUTOR",
    "body": "@varunnvs92 The thing is, the meaning of the current `activeFrom` parameter is actually `expiresOn` and vice-versa. My changes don't change the way the parameters are used, it just fixes the names. In your example, `DateLessThan` will be based on `1000` and `DateGreaterThan` will be based on `2000`. That doesn't make any sense, and is exactly the issue I ran into that led to these changes...I was able to get the method to behave the way I wanted by pretending that `activeFrom` was actually named `expiresOn` and vice-versa. This changeset just fixes the names. If the parameters didn't have names, this changeset wouldn't be needed. I don't know how else to clarify this. I literally did a \"Refactor->Rename\" in IntelliJ for each parameter. I didn't simply swap the parameters in the signature, I renamed them in both the signature and the method body to ensure that their behavior did not change.\n\nPerhaps we should add a test around the existing implementation, merge that in to master first, and then merge that test in to my fork/branch. If we do that, I'm confident the test will continue to pass without needing to change here.\n",
    "performed_via_github_app": null
  },

    "body": "@varunnvs92 I disagree - my changes are non-breaking. Both before and after my changes, the first `Date` was and is used to populate the `DateLessThan` in the policy and the second `Date` was and is used to populate the `DateGreaterThan` in the policy.\n\nIf there was test coverage of the existing code, I expect that the test would continue to pass with these changes without modification of the test.\n",

    "author_association": "CONTRIBUTOR",
    "body": "@mhurne \nAssume a customer who wants to set the activeFrom value as 1000 and expiresOn value as 2000. Currently he would be using this (String resourcePath, Date activeFrom, Date expiresOn, String ipAddress) method as (resource, 1000, 2000, ip). Now if we change the method signature as (String resourcePath, Date expiresOn, Date activeFrom, String ipAddress), the customer's code which is (resource, 1000, 2000, ip) seems like he is using 1000 for expiresOn and 2000 for activeFrom which is breaking change/confuses the customer.\n\nI know that the your implementation works good for new customers but may confuse customers already using this function. I agree that the current code has bug and doesn't work as expected. So fixing the body should be good.\n",

    "created_at": "2016-05-02T23:34:11Z",
    "updated_at": "2016-05-02T23:34:11Z",
    "author_association": "CONTRIBUTOR",
    "body": "@varunnvs92 The thing is, the meaning of the current `activeFrom` parameter is actually `expiresOn` and vice-versa. My changes don't change the way the parameters are used, it just fixes the names. In your example, `DateLessThan` will be based on `1000` and `DateGreaterThan` will be based on `2000`. That doesn't make any sense, and is exactly the issue I ran into that led to these changes...I was able to get the method to behave the way I wanted by pretending that `activeFrom` was actually named `expiresOn` and vice-versa. This changeset just fixes the names. If the parameters didn't have names, this changeset wouldn't be needed. I don't know how else to clarify this. I literally did a \"Refactor->Rename\" in IntelliJ for each parameter. I didn't simply swap the parameters in the signature, I renamed them in both the signature and the method body to ensure that their behavior did not change.\n\nPerhaps we should add a test around the existing implementation, merge that in to master first, and then merge that test in to my fork/branch. If we do that, I'm confident the test will continue to pass without needing to change here.\n",
    "performed_via_github_app": null
  },

    "created_at": "2015-10-12T22:01:52Z",
    "updated_at": "2015-10-12T22:01:52Z",
    "author_association": "NONE",
    "body": "I'm not sure how to confirm that I am submitting under a given license, I've never heard of such a request. I have no objection to my changes being used under the license.\nI wanted to do a string replace to efficiently create a properly escaped CSV by first replacing all `\\` with `\\\\` and then all `,` with `\\,`. String.replaceAll is very slow as it compiles a new Pattern object every time it is called. You can precompile the regex but there's still overhead as it's an overly complicated method. I typed in `StringUtils.<ctrl+space>` to autocomplete not really knowing what I would get, kind of expecting something from Apache Commons. Looked at the source code out of interest. Made a custom version that did multiple replaces in sequence so as to only create one StringBuilder. Later, but before having actually tried it out, I was randomly thinking about it and realised the bug. Tested and confirmed.\n",
    "performed_via_github_app": null
  },
