    "author_association": "CONTRIBUTOR",
    "body": "This is exciting!\n\nThanks for the constructive feedback.\n\nA bit on the DEBUG flag: Yes, its use isn't entirely consistent right now. Generally, the idea is to use it to distinguish between expected/recoverable and unexpected errors.\n\nAccordingly, the \"Record key ... not found\" error in read() should not be wrapped in DEBUG. We should never run into a situation where we read a record that doesn't exist. However, there seems to be a race condition in workload D that causes exactly that.\n\nThe client threads generate keys for the records to be inserted and there is a small time window between the thread generating the key and it actually inserting the record. However, as soon as the key has been generated, that key is considered to be available for other threads to read. (Because transactioninsertkeysequence.lastInt() now returns that key.) That results in the other threads potentially trying to read records that don't yet exist.\n\nThe right fix is, obviously, to take care of the race condition. I just didn't have time, yet, to think about this a little more in depth.\n\nSo, for now, I am mimicking the behavior of other drivers, which don't output an error message and just return an error code.\n\nOr were you referring to something else regarding the flag?\n\nOh, and let me open a ticket regarding the race condition, so that it gets tracked.\n",
    "performed_via_github_app": null
  },

    "updated_at": "2015-07-01T13:43:47Z",
    "author_association": "CONTRIBUTOR",
    "body": "Sorry for the delay. I was traveling.\n\nYes, your interpretation of the retry policy is correct. And, thinking about it again, it's a little... idiosyncratic. It did fit the specific way in which I was using YCSB, but it was probably a little counter-intuitive for everybody else.\n\nSo, instead of documenting its behavior, let's correct the behavior, so that it makes more sense.\n\nNow each write is tried 3 times, followed by delays of 5, 10, and 20 ms, respectively. That's probably a little less surprising than the previous behavior. It'll allow people to see what fraction of their writes actually failed because of server overload. (Instead of failing every subsequent write, once an overload situation is encountered.)\n\nSound good?\n",

    "author_association": "CONTRIBUTOR",
    "body": "I am not entirely sure how to check for TIFFs in the general case to be honest. What I have done now is, instead of looking for GIFs in order to skip the pool, I skip it if the type is not JPG, PNG or PNG_A (which I changed from the previous APNG which means something else btw).\n\nThis way when new types of images are added, the pool skipping will happen automatically unless we add that type to the set of recognized types. Also, I am hoping since I haven't tested, a TIFF will not return JPG or PNG with the current code, so the skipping will happen.\n\nLet me know if this is sufficient.\n",

  {
    "url": "https://api.github.com/repos/cbeust/testng/issues/comments/338460165",
    "html_url": "https://github.com/cbeust/testng/pull/1580#issuecomment-338460165",
    "issue_url": "https://api.github.com/repos/cbeust/testng/issues/1580",
    "id": 338460165,
    "node_id": "MDEyOklzc3VlQ29tbWVudDMzODQ2MDE2NQ==",
    "user": {
      "login": "krmahadevan",
      "id": 909773,
      "node_id": "MDQ6VXNlcjkwOTc3Mw==",
      "avatar_url": "https://avatars0.githubusercontent.com/u/909773?v=4",
      "gravatar_id": "",
      "url": "https://api.github.com/users/krmahadevan",

      "followers_url": "https://api.github.com/users/krmahadevan/followers",
      "following_url": "https://api.github.com/users/krmahadevan/following{/other_user}",
      "gists_url": "https://api.github.com/users/krmahadevan/gists{/gist_id}",
      "starred_url": "https://api.github.com/users/krmahadevan/starred{/owner}{/repo}",
      "subscriptions_url": "https://api.github.com/users/krmahadevan/subscriptions",
      "organizations_url": "https://api.github.com/users/krmahadevan/orgs",
      "repos_url": "https://api.github.com/users/krmahadevan/repos",
      "events_url": "https://api.github.com/users/krmahadevan/events{/privacy}",
      "received_events_url": "https://api.github.com/users/krmahadevan/received_events",
      "type": "User",
      "site_admin": false
    },
    "created_at": "2017-10-22T08:19:13Z",
    "updated_at": "2017-10-22T08:19:13Z",
    "author_association": "COLLABORATOR",
    "body": "@juherr - I am still learning about concurrency. So my explanation might not be convincing. The `ConcurrentLinkedQueue` uses a Compare and Swap based algorithm and doesn't use the typical lock based mechanism. So I thought it would be good if we can go ahead and change sync lists into `ConcurrentLinkedQueue` in places where we are only doing `add` and iteration of the list. The sync list basically resorts to locking and unlocking for every operation which I felt was not necessary if all we wanted was to ensure that there is data consistency, then we could very well use the `ConcurrentLinkedQueue` which also gives this assurance. Please see if [this](https://stackoverflow.com/a/7316863) SO post adds more context.",
    "performed_via_github_app": null
  },
  {
    "url": "https://api.github.com/repos/cbeust/testng/issues/comments/338486792",

      "type": "User",
      "site_admin": false
    },
    "created_at": "2017-10-22T08:19:13Z",
    "updated_at": "2017-10-22T08:19:13Z",
    "author_association": "COLLABORATOR",
    "body": "@juherr - I am still learning about concurrency. So my explanation might not be convincing. The `ConcurrentLinkedQueue` uses a Compare and Swap based algorithm and doesn't use the typical lock based mechanism. So I thought it would be good if we can go ahead and change sync lists into `ConcurrentLinkedQueue` in places where we are only doing `add` and iteration of the list. The sync list basically resorts to locking and unlocking for every operation which I felt was not necessary if all we wanted was to ensure that there is data consistency, then we could very well use the `ConcurrentLinkedQueue` which also gives this assurance. Please see if [this](https://stackoverflow.com/a/7316863) SO post adds more context.",
    "performed_via_github_app": null
  },

    "author_association": "NONE",
    "body": "Hello,\n\nMy change has fixed the class search from class file path\n\nFor ex : input path is c:\\toto\\tata\\src\\main\\java\\com\\test\\Example.class\n\nthe path is split by / or \\ then\n\nbefore code was looking for\nExample.class, => not found (missing package info) then for\nExample.classtest.Example.class => not found (package info build badly)\nthen  for\nExample.classtest.Example.classcom.Example.classtest.Example.class => not\nfound then (...)\n\nafter code is looking for\nExample.class, => not found (missing package info) then for\ntest.Example.class => not found (package info not complete) then for\ncom.test.Example.class => found (full name ok)\n\nThe problem was the bad use of StringBuilder that can not be used to\nprepend strings\n\nThe impact is not only for ant runner, it is for all runner that uses test\nclass dfinition instead of xml test suite definition (applies to maven or\ncommand lines)\n\nI did not impact the classpath a priori.\n\nRegards,\n\nOlivier\n\nOn 10 May 2017 at 08:49, Julien Herr <notifications@github.com> wrote:\n\n> @mourezwell <https://github.com/mourezwell> Thanks for the PR.       "subscriptions_url": "https://api.github.com/users/entryspace/subscriptions",
      "organizations_url": "https://api.github.com/users/entryspace/orgs",
      "repos_url": "https://api.github.com/users/entryspace/repos",
      "events_url": "https://api.github.com/users/entryspace/events{/privacy}",
      "received_events_url": "https://api.github.com/users/entryspace/received_events",
      "type": "User",
      "site_admin": false
    },
    "created_at": "2016-08-21T01:49:00Z",
    "updated_at": "2016-08-21T01:49:00Z",
    "author_association": "CONTRIBUTOR",
    "body": "So I've spent most of the day attempting to add a test as requested, but unfortunately haven't had much luck.\n\nTo give some context - the problem has to do with the default system encoding that's set during a test run (more specifically I believe it gets set when the JVM is started and cannot be changed afterwards).  What I'm not sure of is how best to implement a test for this that will not be dependent on the settings of the system on which it is run.\n\nTo further explain, if you take a look at line 240 of Utils.java, basically what it does is check to see if the specified encoding is null or not.  If not, it uses that encoding in the writer; if it is, then it creates the writer without specifying the encoding, in which case the system default encoding is used.\n\nWhat that means is in many cases it will work just fine; it's only for a select set of characters in somewhat less common scenarios that it becomes an issue.  \n\nMy team encounters it frequently because we use TestNG (through Ant) to run Selenium tests on remote Windows VMs (has to be Windows so we can accurately match actual end user configurations) for an application that handles legal content (where these characters are very common).  I've tried many other ways of getting around this problem over the past couple of years without success (the number of variables involved makes it challenging to come up with a solution that works in all circumstances, both for our nightly regression test runs as well as running tests locally through Eclipse to debug issues); what I ultimately had to do in our internal test suites that leverage TestNG is basically create our own copy of the XMLReporter where I changed that one call from writeFile to writeUtf8File (which is how I know the fix works even if it's difficult to prove).\n\nSorry I can't do much more here; I'll keep investigating to see if I can find a way to reliably reproduce the issue this is meant to address in a way that is not dependent on the default system encoding, but it's not looking too hopeful.\n",
    "performed_via_github_app": null
  },

  {
    "url": "https://api.github.com/repos/cbeust/testng/issues/comments/241181852",
    "html_url": "https://github.com/cbeust/testng/pull/1120#issuecomment-241181852",
    "issue_url": "https://api.github.com/repos/cbeust/testng/issues/1120",
    "id": 241181852,
    "node_id": "MDEyOklzc3VlQ29tbWVudDI0MTE4MTg1Mg==",
    "user": {
      "login": "juherr",
      "id": 254697,
      "node_id": "MDQ6VXNlcjI1NDY5Nw==",

    "url": "https://api.github.com/repos/cbeust/testng/issues/comments/241234048",
    "html_url": "https://github.com/cbeust/testng/pull/1120#issuecomment-241234048",
    "issue_url": "https://api.github.com/repos/cbeust/testng/issues/1120",
    "id": 241234048,
    "node_id": "MDEyOklzc3VlQ29tbWVudDI0MTIzNDA0OA==",
    "user": {
      "login": "entryspace",
      "id": 21134506,
      "node_id": "MDQ6VXNlcjIxMTM0NTA2",
      "avatar_url": "https://avatars1.githubusercontent.com/u/21134506?v=4",
      "gravatar_id": "",
      "url": "https://api.github.com/users/entryspace",
      "html_url": "https://github.com/entryspace",
      "followers_url": "https://api.github.com/users/entryspace/followers",
      "following_url": "https://api.github.com/users/entryspace/following{/other_user}",
      "gists_url": "https://api.github.com/users/entryspace/gists{/gist_id}",
      "starred_url": "https://api.github.com/users/entryspace/starred{/owner}{/repo}",
      "subscriptions_url": "https://api.github.com/users/entryspace/subscriptions",
      "organizations_url": "https://api.github.com/users/entryspace/orgs",
      "repos_url": "https://api.github.com/users/entryspace/repos",
      "events_url": "https://api.github.com/users/entryspace/events{/privacy}",
      "received_events_url": "https://api.github.com/users/entryspace/received_events",
      "type": "User",
      "site_admin": false
    },
    "created_at": "2016-08-21T01:49:00Z",
    "updated_at": "2016-08-21T01:49:00Z",
    "author_association": "CONTRIBUTOR",
    "body": "So I've spent most of the day attempting to add a test as requested, but unfortunately haven't had much luck.\n\nTo give some context - the problem has to do with the default system encoding that's set during a test run (more specifically I believe it gets set when the JVM is started and cannot be changed afterwards).  What I'm not sure of is how best to implement a test for this that will not be dependent on the settings of the system on which it is run.\n\nTo further explain, if you take a look at line 240 of Utils.java, basically what it does is check to see if the specified encoding is null or not.  If not, it uses that encoding in the writer; if it is, then it creates the writer without specifying the encoding, in which case the system default encoding is used.\n\nWhat that means is in many cases it will work just fine; it's only for a select set of characters in somewhat less common scenarios that it becomes an issue.  \n\nMy team encounters it frequently because we use TestNG (through Ant) to run Selenium tests on remote Windows VMs (has to be Windows so we can accurately match actual end user configurations) for an application that handles legal content (where these characters are very common).  I've tried many other ways of getting around this problem over the past couple of years without success (the number of variables involved makes it challenging to come up with a solution that works in all circumstances, both for our nightly regression test runs as well as running tests locally through Eclipse to debug issues); what I ultimately had to do in our internal test suites that leverage TestNG is basically create our own copy of the XMLReporter where I changed that one call from writeFile to writeUtf8File (which is how I know the fix works even if it's difficult to prove).\n\nSorry I can't do much more here; I'll keep investigating to see if I can find a way to reliably reproduce the issue this is meant to address in a way that is not dependent on the default system encoding, but it's not looking too hopeful.\n",
    "performed_via_github_app": null
  },
